text: Your guides tell us there is an unusual ocean current we can use that is safer and quicker, but such precious information will not be cheap to obtain. A small share of the convoy's profits will no doubt ease their tongues...
There are rumors of a quicker way through the reefs to ensure the merchandise reaches the markets quicker, but to turn rumor into reality, the guides demand a share of the profits.
You spot a shipwreck alongside the sea lane. The original occupants are nowhere to be seen. Yet, surprisingly, there is a good amount of cargo still inside.

A rival's convoy is spotted, shattered to pieces leaving only a few left flotsams behind. There are no signs of the lost crew – "enslaved" is the guides' guess. However, there is cargo in the debris; all agree it's best to take what can be carried and move on.
As the convoy comes to a halt for the night, a stranger in a lifeboat closes in. He's begging you to take him with you and saying he'll pay the price by protecting the convoys
A small boat approaches while you are resting. The stranger claims he is a famed adventurer and wishes to join the convoy's retinue! He will protect and fight, but his services come at a price!

The convoy ship stumbles upon a patrol of allies that have been lost for some time. The guides can show them a way back to friendly regions, although this will cause a short delay in getting the Caravan to its destination.

The convoy ship was being tracked… followed. After moving into a defensive stance and loading the cannon, the potential enemies emerged and turned out to be friends – a group of mercenaries who have fought alongside and spilled blood with you in the past; more like friends than mere colleagues, in fact.

A convoy ship draped in the trappings of Ind travels this road. It slows to a stop as your own approaches. Growls come from the guards whose faces remain hidden by voluminous silk scarfs, their gloved hands hover over large scimitars resting on their hips. One infers that the Merchant Lord should approach. He does so cautiously and sees a large cage hidden behind fine curtains.\\n\\nThe Merchant Lord returns, his eyes gleaming, for he has seen what lies in the cage. Yet he won't say what... only that Ind is known as the Land of a Thousand Gods for a reason.\\n\\n"We are blessed," he stammers.
Up ahead, pirates have set up a trap, waiting in a defensive position. Pirates are demanding cargo from your convoy ship as a toll to continue. Refuse and they will attack.
Pirates appear before the convoy ships and demand a toll – part of the cargo as payment. They look ready for a fight.

Your scouts have discovered a pirates preparing an ambush. There is an alternative route, but it will add days to the journey. Or, perhaps, without the element of surprise, the enemy can be beaten and the Gilded Route won't incur a delay?

Pathfinders have scouted ahead and discovered an ambush is being set. There is another sea lane that will veer us away from danger, but delay the Gilded Route's arrival. The other option is to take the convoy ship along the original route, repel the ambushers, and arrive on time.

A pirate ship approaches our ship and they're not open for negotiations. They're demanding all or nothing. If we want to avoid the battle, we must leave someone as a rearguard in a small ship and their chance of survival is low.

A rift tears through reality and Daemons disgorge, hungry for mortal souls. They quickly catch the scent of the convoy ship and give chase. The only escape is to sacrifice some defenders and hope they can fend off the Daemons while the rest flee. Or, if you wish to retain your honour – stay your ground, and face the Daemons!
Gilded Route Encounter! The Unusual Current
Gilded Route Encounter! A Quicker Way
Gilded Route Encounter! A Gift from Ind

Distraught, disillusioned, banktrupt. The once great House Den Euwe has gambled and lost their final wealth as their pride and heir, Egmond den Euwe, failed to capatilize on the Cathayan Market. For once, the Van de Kuypers need do nothing to neutralise a rival house but watch as they implode. But as in all things we see opportunity in others misfortune. For a fee we could pay off the debts racked up by House Den Euwe and take over their trade mission in the far East. Although there's something inherently off about Egmond, he has skill and could proof valuable.

Long has there been a stalemate between the Directorate and the Shadows of the Wasteland, as in truth they are equally corrupt. As long as those who disappear from Marienburg in to the clutches of the Shadows are of low class society, the directors hardly care. But now the mortal man of Marienburg have grown arrogant. Thinking their own rings and networks can take over the lucrative trade. They are demanding blood money, as always these shortminded fools tend to solve everything with a few silverlings.
They shall know the cold grip of Death
A small fee for a big price
You pay the directorate and expand operations

Egmond's voice, even his very body slowly begins to transform. His erratic demeanour no longer attributable to sickness, the people arround him know there is something deeply off with him. Forcing them along on his quest ordered by Tsien-Tsin to travel to North Egmond now faces the true moment that shall define his faith. \\n\\n Tsien-Tsin, or as is clear now - Tzeentch, orders him to rendezvous with the cunning Vilitch the Curseling. May they together dip Cathay in everlasting conversion. Yet somewhere, deep down Egmond still has the urge to resist. The spirit of his Nipponese ancestors pushing towards the light, and Tsien-Tsin out. It is time to pick your faith.
Tsien-Tsin's call overwhelms you as fully give in to the engulfing power of change.
I am honour bond to serve my family
Your ancestral Nipponese blood prevents the corruption to spread any further, and your vision becomes clear once more.

The Master Speaker of the Burgerhof is a populist, a demagogue and corrupt. Yet his talent with words and speeches has gained him the support of most of the lower-class society. They see in him one of their own kind and class. Little do they know, the Speaker only seeks power and money and a seat among those his own supporters despise. He's made a daring yet threatening proposal, offering his services and thus the support of his following for a price.
One does not threaten a Van de Kuypers
How much harm could a demogogue do?
Men employed by the various guilds from Marienburg, often directly from the Marienburg State-Army
A group of mercenaries offers their services
Based on the Merchant Lord's innate trait, foreigners might be tempted to join this convoy.
Gilded Route Complete! - New recruitment option

Drawn by the prospect of wealth and adventure, mercenaries and guildsmen are willing to join the convoy. The Merchant Lords background has played a part in the type of mercenaries willing to join your ranks. We should choose wisely by bolstering the convoy where it is weakest.

The great Empire of Man exists as little more than a pack of squabbling animals, power-hungry Electors and their backwards peoples desperate to better themselves at the cost of their neighbors. None would admit to betraying their Emperor, of course. But in every one of their rancid hearts lies one simple thought - "I could rule better." A seed that, if watered and nurtured, can grow into something great and terrible.

The great Empire of Man exists as little more than a pack of squabbling animals, power-hungry Electors and their backwards peoples desperate to better themselves at the cost of their neighbors. None would admit to betraying their Emperor, of course. But in every one of their rancid hearts lies one simple thought - "I could rule better." A seed that, if watered and nurtured, can grow into something great and terrible.

A lonely Caravan has been spotted trundling through nearby land, bearing the banners of Cathay. No doubt the products of the so-called Celestial Empire would be worth snatching for ourselves, yet such spoils are not likely to lie unguarded.\\n\\nA choice between killing or caution. It seems the answer is clear...
Convoy Encounter! A Dwarf Too Far
A wandering Convoy of Dwarf has entered our site. Should we attack them for a fresh new set of slaves?

Signs of a troop column have been spotted ahead. Judging by the tracks, it looks as though this force has been moving without sleep or pause. Cresting the next hill, the gleam of bone and gold can be seen throughout the army. A host of Tomb Kings, richly adorned, is marching through this area. Their destination is unclear, but their opulence is not. We could descend upon them, and claim their riches for ourselves!
It seems like there was a big battle nearby, we can use it to raise more troops or use its magical power to empower the troops.

Traversing realms is hungry work if these Daemons we've encountered are to be believed. You could choose to sate their gluttonous appetites in the hopes of avoiding a fight. Yet, on the other hand, death would solve their hunger too…

Unfortunate wretches of many races travel the sea to gather wealth. Yet while out on assignment, even our Convoy knows not to pass up the opportunity to attain more of the "right tools" for the job, having encountered a High Elf host from whom much profit could be forcibly reaped – both in long-limbed Labourers and loot reaped from beardless corpses.
A great artifact of dark magic has come to our grasp. However, we need to decide which equipment we should empower to give the Convoy the greatest chance of successfully repelling any threats.

The strength of an Ogre is unmatched anywhere! At least, that's what this group of rotund mercenaries assured us when offering to guard our trade Convoy on its route. Their claim is ridiculous but the extra muscle wouldn't go amiss. Ogres' services, however, certainly would not come free of charge.

While traveling through a maze of chaotic passages, our Convoy encountered a mysterious-looking portal, simply begging for further exploration. Both rewards and dangers could lie beyond its swirling vortex; is such a risk worth taking?

Beyond the portal lay a bounty of Cargo, ripe for repossession. If someone was willing to leave it in the open like that, then surely nobody will miss it... except, of course, for the angry Daemons that greeted us upon our return, who demanded the return of their stolen horde.\\n\\nWe could fight to keep it, though simply returning it may grant an even greater reward...
Convoy Encounter! Portals: The Final Chapter

Who needs Cargo when you can secure the services of a party of vicious Daemons? On your generous return of the loot, two groups step forward, offering to rip your enemies into tiny, bloodstained pieces. Delightful! The bickering and chest-pounding that ensues between the groups is less pleasing. It seems you're going to have to choose...

Without warning, a sudden chill rushes through the bones. A torrent of whispers floods the heads of the warriors, all repeating the same thing.\\n\\n[[i]]"Make a sacrifice, and overwhelming power shall be yours…"[[/i]]
The Convoy Master scouts a quicker route which would make up for the lost time. However, looking at the weather, that shortcut would result in some damaged 'goods'.
This ship is filled with rats! Unless we have dealt with them sooner or we will have to make a stop to refill our supplies. Maybe we need to track them all and kill them.

Fog has descended around our Convoy. The smell is putrid and shuffling shapes can be glimpsed in the haze. This land around us teems with their shambling forms; we have stumbled, unwittingly, into the domain of the Undead. These creatures can be confronted head-on and the wretches put down for good or, alternatively, we can order some of our number to distract them while we make our escape, though they will ultimately have no hope against the necrotic masses.

Stealth is possibly not the strong suit of our would-be ambushers, who visibly await our Convoy from some rather questionable 'hiding' places. We could avoid them easily, of course, but it almost seems a disservice not to show them what a true ambush looks like...

A guide has tracked down our Convoy, offering to lead the way to our destination in exchange for a reasonable donation to his pockets. His price is frankly extortionate, but as they say in business, time is of the essence.

A cacophony of roars and feral shrieks rings out ahead of your Convoy – a Dark Elf Beastmaster approaches! By the look of his shackled beasts, he is recently returned from an expedition into Norsca and poses little threat, his retinue of hunters visibly weary and battered from their run-ins with the Northmen and critters of the tundra. With a tired Druchii sneer, he offers the Convoy one of his creatures in exchange for some slaves. Though we care little for the Dark Elf’s plight, such a beast could be useful against future threats.

The day may have just begun, but one of the scouts has already spotted a wide, flat, stone platform in an isolated area. A series of eight steps leads to an eight-sided arena, with grooves carved in the floor to drain the blood spilled. Unmistakably, this is a Khornate combat shrine: the perfect location to tutor troops and beat the weakness out of them.
Convoy Encounter! The Path of Storm
A strong current is in front of our eyes. We can traverse this rough current and reach our destination sooner, but it may take the lives of some of our weaker personnel.
Maybe you'll be of some use
Let's see what you can do
I hope insurance pay for this general average.
The Gilded Route's slender profits are not to be shared with these chancers. We shall take the usual route and get to our destination anyway.
Pay the price and arrive faster… maybe.
These guides are not to be trusted, they could be leading us into an ambush. Stay on the known route.
Entrepreneurs take chances. Agree to the profit-share and see us reach the markets before our rivals.
Your guides mutter that to take such cargo is cursed. Perhaps it is best to leave it.
If you don't take it, someone else will! This is an enterprise run for profit, so let's make more money!
There are crates stamped with the sigil of Shallya. Within are medicines and tinctures that can be put to good use.
Exotic spices are worth far more. Add this to your convoy ship and see your wealth greatly increase.
No, taking on strangers mid-journey is not advised by the council of Burgomeisters for good reason.
The stranger may prove useful should the convoy ship come under threat, but they have a strange look in their eyes…
The Gilded route doesn't need the additional protection, and picking up strangers mid-journey is never a good idea.
Another hired sword will bolster the convoy ship's protection, and if they are as good as they claim, should be worth the price.
Originally sent to hunt down your enemies, they are now ready to restock on ammunition and head into battle.
Eager to wet their blades with enemy blood once more, they will fight for you if they are but shown a way back home.
Keen fighters wish to return home and fight in your armies once more!
These missile specialists run low on ammunition. Send them back so they can restock and join your armies!
On arrival, the cargo held in the convoy ship has doubled in size and value! This might be the most profitable venture yet!
The convoy ship no longer holds mundane cargo, but exquisite weapons of exceptional quality instead. These should not be sold, but retained for our armies!
A wise man once said, "Better to pay than fight all day".
We will not be held to ransom by these yokels!
Perhaps on this occasion giving up some of the cargo is the best option.
We shall brook no delay! Slay these would-be ambushers.
Best to arrive, even if it's late.
We know they are there, they cannot surprise us – we can win this!
This will incur a delay, but we shall at least arrive intact.
Remember the names of the brave ones who stayed behind to let us escape!
The Dark Powers shall not claim our souls!
Remember the names of the brave ones who stayed behind to let us escape!
Refuse to pay off the debts
You pay off any outstanding debts and absorb the Cathayan trade mission started by House Den Euwe.
There's no business case in the Eastern Trade. Neglect this opportunity.
Let them flounder in their own failure a little longer.
One lousy Caravan isn't worth the bother. The Cathayans can keep their lives for today, and their paltry cargo.
We were short for short slaves
Fight them! Break their ancient bones and seize their wealth.
We must not be distracted from our goal. Leave them to their Unlife.
Empower the existing army with the corpses
Hungry are they? Well in that case they can fill their bellies with our blades!
What's a few sacrifices for the many? It was probably time to cull the weak anyway – these Daemons are doing you a favour!
We will crush this host and make our consignment even more lucrative than it already is!
Hostilities and losses can be easily avoided if we just keep moving.
To end a fight as quickly and easily as possible, one needs the capacity to deal the lethal blow.
One who can endure the most dangerous and prolonged attacks has the best chance of landing a lethal counterattack.
Who are we to leave these poor Ogre mercenaries without work? Times are hard, after all!
You are a strong and independent. Who needs an Ogre anyway!
A detour through a strange portal in a dark, underground passageway… When you put it like that, what could go wrong?
We have no time to waste
We have no time to go wandering through portals. We must continue on our journey!
We found it and it's ours! If these Daemons love their Cargo so much, they shouldn't have just left it lying around!
We don't need their goods, anyway. Grateful Daemons, on the other hand…
Powerful Daemons for our army? Yes please!
Obviously these are the superior Daemons... Think of the bloodshed!
The urge to sacrifice one of the retinue into this strange formation is hard to ignore; it feels like there is great power to be had here.
Ignore it – it is best not to meddle in things we do not understand.
We can handle a few off-road chicanes – any potential losses will probably cost us less in the long run than gaining a reputation for tardiness.
We should stick to the main route and avoid exposing the cargo to any unnecessary risks.
Kill some rats and reduce the length of our journey? Sounds like a win-win!
We don't know how many rats are in this convoy. The last thing we need is to be overwhelmed by the vermin!
The smell of gunpowder is preferable to the smell of rotting flesh. Eliminate them!
Their sacrifice allows us to continue without further losses.
Their attempts at an ambush are frankly so embarrassing it would be an insult to Hashut to let them live.
Let them get whoever is next
They might get lucky one day. Probably not any time soon, though.
We don't need any guidance! We have an excellent sense of direction, thank you very much!
We need to reach our destination quickly; this guide had better be worth the price!
With this beast in our Convoy’s ranks, assailants will not consider us an easy target.
It would be foolish to part with some of our cargo – we have no need for this beast and can adequately protect ourselves.
We can brook no frailty in this Convoy. This is time well invested.
Training is always important, but we must not lose track of time.
We cannot risk this untested path.
Our troops can handle a few loss of lives.

Seeing the man in person reveals the truth; a power-hungry madman willing to risk the entire Empire for his own arrogance. The other provinces must know the fate of treachery, a crime repaid in blood, no matter who backed him.

Hans acted rashly and cost the lives of many good men, but your strength has forced him to see the error of his ways. His recompense to the dead will be defending the outer borders of the Empire, in one of it's many Forts.
From Mad Count to Mad Emperor?

A dilemma will allow the Directorate to fund foreign armies and bribe Faction Leaders to wage war against Marienburg's rivals.\\n\\nPerforming this Rite will cost gold, and the dilemma choices will be free. The amount of gold spent will be gifted to the target faction.
Either call upon Manann's fury to frighten rogue pirates or hunt them down for faction wide boons
Either call upon Manann's fury to frighten rogue pirates or hunt them down for faction wide boons
Either call upon Manann's fury to frighten rogue pirates or hunt them down for faction wide boons
Either call upon Manann's fury to frighten rogue pirates or hunt them down for faction wide boons
Either call upon Manann's fury to frighten rogue pirates or hunt them down for faction wide boons
Either call upon Manann's fury to frighten rogue pirates or hunt them down for faction wide boons
Either call upon Manann's fury to frighten rogue pirates or hunt them down for faction wide boons
Either call upon Manann's fury to frighten rogue pirates or hunt them down for faction wide boons
Call upon Manann's Fury to scatter the rogue pirates
Call upon Manann's Fury to scatter the rogue pirates
